events.description: Discussions between Tehran and Washington scheduled for Friday in Oman to address various issues including the nuclear program.
Release of US crude and distillate inventory data for the week ending January 30th.

facts.fact_text: US heating oil futures fell below $2.40 per gallon.

evidences.evidence_text: US heating oil futures slipped below $2.40 per gallon after a brief two session rebound

facts.fact_text: Iranian Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi stated that talks with the US will occur in Oman on Friday.

evidences.evidence_text: Iranian Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi said discussions will take place in Oman on Friday, a plan later confirmed by a White House official

facts.fact_text: US crude inventories decreased by approximately 3.5 million barrels in the week ending January 30th.

evidences.evidence_text: EIA data showed US crude inventories fell by about 3.5 million barrels in the week to January 30th

facts.fact_text: Distillate stocks saw a draw of about 5.55 million barrels in the prior week.

evidences.evidence_text: distillate stocks posted a sharp draw of roughly 5.55 million barrels the prior week

claims.claim_text: Lower crude oil benchmarks reduced refinery costs and limited price increases for heating oil.

evidences.evidence_text: softer crude oil benchmarks lowered refinery input costs and capped upside

claims.claim_text: Expectations of warmer weather are suppressing demand for heating oil.

evidences.evidence_text: warmer weather expectations continued to restrain demand

claims.claim_text: The upcoming US-Iran talks have reduced market anxiety regarding Middle East supply disruptions.

evidences.evidence_text: easing fears that an escalation in the Middle East could disrupt energy flows

claims.claim_text: The sharp draw in distillate stocks confirms high consumption during the recent cold spell.

evidences.evidence_text: confirming strong consumption that already materialised during the recent Arctic cold spell

evidence.evidence_text: easing fears that an escalation in the Middle East could disrupt energy flows
warmer weather expectations continued to restrain demand
softer crude oil benchmarks lowered refinery input costs and capped upside
EIA data showed US crude inventories fell by about 3.5 million barrels
